Author: Dylan McGrath
Keywords: Computers And Peripherals, Consumer Electronics & Appliances, ICs, Mergers & Acquisitions, Semiconductor Design & Manufacturing, Semiconductors
Article: SAN FRANCISCO â Broadcom called a request by Qualcomm to enter into a non-disclosure agreement and continue negotiations about its $117 billion proposal to acquire the company “disingenuous” and “engagement theater,” suggesting that Qualcomm is feigning interest in negotiating a deal to delay a proxy vote by Qualcomm stockholders that had been set for next week.Â Â  “Broadcom does not believe that the process outlined by Qualcomm today is designed to lead to a prompt agreement,” Broadcom said. Broadcom also suggested that Qualcomm is going through the motions to demonstrate due diligence to Â stockholders â many of which want the two sides to reach an agreement. “Broadcom believes Qualcomm's sudden request to enter into an NDA is a result of Qualcomm finally beginning to recognize the will of its stockholders,” Broadcom said in a statement Monday (Feb. 26), hours after Qualcomm made public a letter from Qualcomm Chairman Paul Jacobs to Broadcom President and CEO Hock Tan stating that Qualcomm's board had authorized the company to provide Broadcom with a marked up version of Broadcom's acquisition proposal that would resolve “all issues between the two companies other than price.” The main sticking points between the companies have centered on Qualcomm's concern that the transaction gain regulatory approval. Qualcomm's board has twice voted to unanimously reject Broadcom's offers based on price and concerns over regulatory approval. While the companies appear to have made headway on sticking points surrounding the acquisition proposal during a second meeting of company representatives held Feb. 23, they appear to be far apart on the price Broadcom would pay to acquire Qualcomm. Broadcom last week cut its offer for Qualcomm to $117 billion from $121 billion after Qualcomm agreed to up the ante to acquire NXP Semiconductors, a condition that most observers agreed was essential in order for Qualcomm to complete the $44 billion buy of NXP. Qualcomm said Monday that its board of directors is unanimous that all of the proposals made by Broadcom to acquire Qualcomm “materially undervalues Qualcomm.” Qualcomm further said its board “encourages Broadcom to enter into a mutual due diligence and price negotiations.”  Paul Jacobs  Qualcomm's statement Monday appeared to provide the clearest indication yet that Qualcomm's board is open to reaching a deal with Broadcom. However, Broadcom said the “disingenuous” process outlined by Qualcomm “defers the question of price, even after Qualcomm's Presiding Director Tom Horton last week publicly stated that the Qualcomm board views Broadcom's proposed price as 'not even close.'” In the letter, Jacobs proposes that the two sides enter an NDA and enter into “bilateral due diligence.” Jacobs said Qualcomm would deliver the proposed NDA to Broadcom's counsel.Â  Qualcomm stockholders are set to decide next week whether to elect six nominees to its board put forward by Broadcom in a proxy fight that will likely decide the fate of Broadcom's bid to acquire Qualcomm in what would be the largest high-tech acquisition in history. Broadcom's statement painted a different picture of the Feb. 23 meeting than Qualcomm's statement, saying among other things that Qualcomm refused to confirm that Qualcomm would hold its previously scheduled stockholder vote on March 6.Â Â  “Qualcomm's owners deserve the chance to preserve Broadcom's $79 per Qualcomm share offer,” Broadcom said. “Broadcom, as a stockholder of Qualcomm, will fight to ensure the ability of Qualcomm's owners to determine Qualcomm's future.” â Dylan McGrath is the editor-in-chief of EE Times.
